bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, October 5, 1940

div1.p: Hench discusses the inclusion of Cooke for the Lazear memorial ceremony.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, October 5, 1940
div1.p:
I enclose the list of friends and relatives to whom you might send invitations.
I confess this worries me a bit. I don't want to be put in the position of looking
as if I were advertising myself. The list of relatives is quite all right, and
I think the list of some friends out of town is all right probably. I have in-
cluded about twelve names of my best friends in Rochester, but I hope no one
will get the impression that I am circularizing the Mayo Clinic.

I have my own cap and gown. I wore it at Lafayette, Two years ago in London
and Oxford at the International Congress, we had to wear academic gowns so often
it seemed quite natural. Unfortunately, Mrs. Kahler cannot come, but she would be
delighted to receive an invitation.

I am glad you decided to ask Dr. Cooke. I think he has never received any
recognition of any sort except, of course, the Congressional Medal. I had an
air-mail answer from General Kean yesterday. He said, “I entirely agree with you
that Dr. Cooke is quite on the same plane as the mosquito men. At the time that
these men volunteered, every doctor in Havana and in the United States would have
said that the infected bedding squad ran the greater danger, as infection by
fomites (infected bedding and clothing) was universally accepted as a means of
transmission, while mosquito transmission was a discredited theory. In addition
the wearing of dead men's garments and sleeping in sheets soiled with black vomit
and excreta made it, as Reed said of it, a trying ordeal. I think I would have
chosen the mosquitos every time before the Finlay theory had been demonstrated.”
Incidentally, the story goes that when Cooke and his two associate volunteers
first entered the foul smelling experimental building, within a few minutes, they
rushed out and one vomited. In introducing Dr. Cooke, you might polish this story
up a bit, and say that after forty years, Washington and Jefferson wishes to replace
the lost meal: This may not be very delicate, but it is pertinent.

I haven't heard from Dr. Sawyer yet, but I have tentatively revamped my entire
idea on my talk. I suspect that I had better confine myself entirely to a brief
tribute to Lazear, and mention very little about the general story and even mention
the three honored guests only in passing. That being the case, I will hardly need
any slides and would really not have to refer to any souvenir photographs. Never-
theless, I think your idea is an excellent one, and I am sure it would please the
honored guests. Therefore, I have picked out and am sending you by separate post
today, a dozen photographs from which you can choose. May I suggest that they be
numbered and somewhere on the inside of the program, these numbers be identified.

I enclose with them a photograph of Moran and one of Kissinger, made out to
me. But the autographs are such that they will not interfere with your publicity
purposes. I am sure they would not object, as both of these photographs have been
published elsewhere. I have none of Cooke. I wrote a month ago asking for one
- 2 -
of his old photographs. I suggest that you write him for one of his new ones.
I am very proud of the ones of Moran and Kissinger to me, and I sincerely hope
you will ask your photographer to take special care of them and if possible, re-
turn not only them but also the others, or save them until I come.

I enclose also, for you to keep should you wish, one of the Metropolitan
Life's little booklets on the yellow fever affair. You will notice about Kissinger
and Moran on page 16. Now

Now as to the photographs. If you can do so, I would suggest that you use
the following:
Photograph 11 a. Model of Camp Columbia Post Hospital. There are
no adequate photographs. This is where the preliminary work
by Reed, Lazear, etc. was done. In fact, all the work until
after Lazear's death. Lazear's house is the one in the upper
left hand corner. The laboratory that Reed and Lazear used
is the little building I have indicated with a pencil.
Photograph 15. The heretofore unpublished photograph of Agramonte,
Lazear, and Carroll, loaned me by courtesy of Dr. Agramonte's
daughter.
Photograph 28. The outside of Las Animas Hospital, showing the room
where Lazear was presumably bitten. At least he did much of
his work, collecting infected blood in this yellow fever ward.
Photograph A. The room in Las Animas Hospital where Lazear was
bitten, showing a memorial plaque to Lazear.
Photograph 56. Showing the old San Jose farm house, where Camp
Lazear was. I know that the Rojas family would get a great
kick out of having this photograph shown, if you can bring it in.

I would then select one or two of the old photographs of Camp Lazear. See my
two labeled ones, and also numbers 20 and 21. I have had a composite drawing made
of Camp Lazear showing all the tents and buildings visible in the various pictures
that I have collected. No photograph shows them all. This drawing is being photo-
graphed this week and you just might prefer it to the actual photograph. If you
do, I will send it; in fact, I will send it anyhow and you can use it if you wish.

Next choice. I think it would be nice to show one of the three pictures of
the sign and memorial fence at the proposed site but really false site of Camp Lazear.
This was really not the site of Camp Lazear, but we have now identified it as the
site of the tent hospital where Dr. Lazear died of yellow fever. The only reason
I am sending the one of Mary and me in it is that it happens to show more than the
other two.

Last selection. You might want one of the statues to Dr. Lazear. I have sent
you four choices.

As you see, I have given you a selection in historical sequence, and you
and your photographer can decide which you want, if any. I also have a photo-
graph of the Congressional Medal, especially designed and given to those twenty-
odd men who participated in the yellow fever experiments. I think this would
be very nice to add. It is small and could be more or less tucked away in the
corner of the composite photograph. I will have one printed Monday. Remember
that the U.S. government thought so highly of the contribution of these men that
they not only gave them this Congressional Medal and a life pension but created
for the first time a U.S. Army Roll of Honor, which is published each year in
perpetuity and which, by the way, contains only the names of the yellow fever
men. There is no other Army Roll of Honor. Since Cooke's name was on that
Roll, you will appreciate we think he deserves an invitation.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
